caseTitle: GHANA LOTTO OPERATORS ASSOCIATION v NATIONAL LOTTERY AUTHORI
summary: In Ghana Lotto Operators Association v National Lottery Authority, the Supreme Court of Ghana addressed a constitutional reference on whether the National Lotto Act, 2006 (Act 722) violated Articles 33(5), 35(1), and 36(2)(b) of the 1992 Constitution. The plaintiffs, private lotto operators, challenged the Act's monopoly provisions and a directive to surrender lottery equipment, arguing infringements on economic freedom and private sector rights. The Court held that Article 33(5), which recognizes unenumerated democratic rights, was not violated, as the plaintiffs failed to clearly identify such rights or demonstrate their applicability. Article 35(1), concerning national sovereignty, was deemed too general to be infringed by the Act. Regarding Article 36(2)(b), which promotes private sector participation, the Court found it non-justiciable, distinguishing Ghana’s Constitution from India’s, where directive principles are explicitly non-enforceable. Despite the absence of an express non-justiciability clause, the Court interpreted Chapter 6 as aspirational and not directly enforceable in courts, thus upholding Act 722. The ruling clarified the limits of constitutional enforcement of economic policy directives in Ghana.
verdict: Act 722 does not violate Articles 33(5), 35(1), or 36(2)(b) of the 1992 Constitution
rationaleHighlights: Article 33(5) does not independently create enforceable rights without clear identification of unenumerated democratic freedoms
Article 35(1) is a general sovereignty clause not violated by economic legislation
Directive Principles under Chapter 6, including Article 36(2)(b), are aspirational and non-justiciable in the absence of express enforcement mechanisms
The right to work, even if recognized internationally, does not include an unregulated right to operate lotteries
Courts must distinguish between enforceable rights and policy objectives in constitutional interpretation
